I was recently made aware of this topic and am very intrigued, the obvious question I had was
 ‚Äúwhat about the rapists and murderers‚Äù
 I was excited to hear that exact question posed here in this video.

Yes, we know that the current system isn‚Äôt working, that‚Äôs why we‚Äôre here watching this video, what is the alternative that this movement offers? ‚ÄúPrevent it from happening‚Äù, I love that idea, but what, specifically, is the solution for someone who is found to be a murder or rapist, or a serial murder or rapist, or perhaps a serial murder or rapist whom is affected with psychopathy or sociopathy? replies.author: @Ca-yr2rz
replies.text:
I had the same question and after some reading, I can share with you one option: caring about the victim needs.

Of course the first steps are prevention, detection, education. In a society free of jails, the resources and the community must be focused in the systematic problems that are the roots of these kind of conducts. This is very important, because they're the actions that change the dynamics we currently have (very well explained in the video).

But if the assault is still commited, the community should center their attention on the victim and helping them to overcome the traumatic experience. What do they need to feel safe again? What do they need from the perpetrator? What can we do about it, as their community? 

I hope I could convey the idea, english is not my first language and I read about this answer in a translation in mine, but it's in a chapter of Penal Abolitionism: Papers from the Penal Law, Abolition and Anarchism 
Conference Volume I by J. M. Moore.

author: @Noooiiiissseee
text:
Great video, but there's still a bit of an issue.

Your section on "What do we do with criminals" still isn't answered. You used a lot of stats to show why what we're doing now isn't working, which is good, but it seems a bit like a deflection.

Even if we say for the sake of argument that only 1% of crimes are done by truly horrible and broken people, what gets done about them? It's easy to say "just fix the issues that create them" but some people have a normal life and end up being horrific monsters anyway. What do we do about these people? What about the ones that no amount of therapy or help will work on? We can't pretend these types don't exist just because it's convenient to our argument. There NEEDS to be a solid answer for this aspect of the argument, otherwise the vast majority of people will never be on board, because why would they advocate for something that makes them feel unsafe?

replies.author: @bil-v6h
replies.text: Alternatives could be restorative justice practices, community-based rehabilitation programs, mental health and substance abuse treatment, housing and employment support, and transformative justice initiatives. By expanding the range of responses available, communities can better meet the needs of those impacted by harm while fostering healing and reconciliation. I still agree with you that there needs to be more imagination in considering the specifics of restorative and transformative justice initiatives. Seems as if there is a crisis of imagination.

replies.author: @Anton15243
replies.text:
@bil-v6h The suggested alternatives are all good and way better than what we have now IMO, but it leaves the problem that, for it to truly work, the wrongdoer must be willing to accept that they did wrong and to make amends. As such, it begs the question: "What about amoral sociopaths that will just pretend to change their minds only to immediately get back to harming others? Or those that are entirely unresponsive to treatment?"
In which situation, I'd settle and say that "Okay, we can have them removed from society, but just for these guys and on comfortable terms (think Norwegian low-security prisons)". Or just "Look, we're not trying to create a perfect system, only a better one"

replies.author: @Anton15243
replies.text: Thegingerbreadm4n You are right that the subject of both free will and the boundaries of addiction are contested ones. But I don't see how that correlates to the questions of "What do we do with those that refuse to change their ways to more prosocial alternatives". I call them "wrongdoers" not really because they have a "wrong" worldview, but rather because what they're doing is often antisocial (in the "being a jerk" sense). Even if you think that we're all a mix of quantum randomness and relativistic physics, the question only changes from "How do we convince them to change their ways" to "How do we fire up the neural patterns associated with seeing things our way"

A tale of sorrow, a secret that seeps,
Through veins of a nation, a land so grand,
But marred by the grip of a profit-driven hand.

The night is a canvas, painted in fear,
As sirens wail, drawing near and near,
Innocence trembles, the vulnerable weep,
In the name of the law, so many secrets they keep.

Injustice, a specter, wears a badge so bold,
Trading lives for dollars, hearts turning cold,
For the scales of justice, heavy with gold,
In the name of the system, our stories untold.

Behind bars, where hope once thrived,
Now a factory of despair, where dreams are contrived,
For profit, they cage the souls of the weak,
Humanity's price, in tears we all speak.

Families shattered, communities torn,
In this cycle of pain, so many are born,
But still, in the darkness, a flicker remains,
A whisper of change, breaking free from these chains.

Let us rise, with courage and might,
To mend what is broken, to stand for what's right,
In unity, we'll rewrite this tale of despair,
Where justice for all is a burden we share.

In this boom of the heart, let our voices resound,
For the sake of the lost, in freedom we're bound,
No more profiting from others' demise,
Let love and compassion wipe tears from our eyes.

For in our unity, in our collective cry,
We'll rewrite the story, reach for the sky,
A world where justice is blind to all gold,
In this heartfelt pursuit, our spirits unfold.

text:
I think the discussion we need to have more is what we as a society do with violent people who are not violent as a result of socioeconomic circumstances. This is obviously a small minority, but they do exist, and the Paul Bernardos, and the Ted Bundys of the world are what your average citizen cares about. 

I think need to confront the fact that what society did with these people before formalized law enforcement or prisons was some form of what we might call mob violence. Now with the history of America being what it is, we know that mob violence can be extremely ugly and racist form. But given the immense consequences of formalizing arrest and enforcement powers in the hands of a small number of individuals, is the system we created that much better. Are we safer with the police than with the so called mob? Given that average citizens could not defend themselves from the mafia for fear of imprisonment for vigilantism, while that mafia ran with impunity because the police were on the take, the answer might be no.

author: @seanmcfarlandart
text:
I agree with so much of this but I would appreciate explicitly stating the abolitionist position on violent crime. Sex crime bam, slam dunk you nailed it but the omission of violent crime is glaring and comes off as evasive.

I've seen the responses that you've provided to commenters with similar concerns, and it seems like the argument is that with substantive social change violent crime will be eliminated at the root.  Articulating that in the video proper, would likely save you some time in the comment section, unless this a 4D chess move to drive engagement, in which case well done.

 I don't believe it myself, I think interpersonal violence is something far more intrinsic to the human condition than we would like to admit, but moving to an abolitionist system is still a laudable goal and "what we do with the inexplicably violent now that the prisons are gone," is so far off it's not likely to be a real concern until much, much later.

replies.author: @olurinatti
replies.text: Respectfully, you're supposed to think when you watch and read materials. Authors/creators are not supposed to have to spell out every thing you could possibly imagine, they're supposed to provide you enough info for you to start thinking, asking questions, and exploring things and connecting dots on your own. It's a 12 minute overview/intro to abolition, it can't serve as an end all be all that leaves nothing for anyone else to think about, that's simply not possible. I emphasized in the video that abolition is about designing systems that address and prevent certain harms for the VERY FIRST TIME so why would you take that to mean I or any one person should have that system already unilaterally predesigned. I'm exposing you to an idea, not becoming the architect of our future.

Well, I think the point of this whole thing is to find the underlying reasons as to why people "commit crimes". It's to try to get people the help they need before resort to breaking the law. Most offenses are a result of poverty, so we have to adress that, as well as really invest in mental health services. We also have to make sure the people incarcerated right now get rehabilitated into society to prevent further offenses on their part. All of this would go a long way to prevent people committing criminal offenses. 

As for sexual violence, I think that mostly comes down to social awareness. A huge part of that is raising our boys in a way where they treat women like human beings, where they take no for an answer, just raise them to be respectable human beings. Of course everyone needs to be taught to respect boundaries regardless of gender, but we have to recognise that in most cases women are the victims. Social awareness also helps to not let people get away with these things, so we also empower victims. 

If all of this works as it should in an ideal situation, we'd probably eliminate like 90-99% of crimes. We might never reach this, but the point is to work towards this either way. And if we only have a handful of people resorting to criminal offenses, would we even need prisons then? Maybe we would need a facility for the absolute worst of the worst, but that's a problem to solve then. The point of all of this is just to work towards a society where prisons are no longer necessary. If there are no longer anyone who would justifyably need to be locked up, why keep empty prisons around? That's at least how I understand it

replies.text: @SouthPilot Rewatch the video, genius. Abolition isn't the immediate release of all criminals, but the slow and gradual process by which we bring about a world wherein such crimes are less likely to happen, and rehabilitate criminals when they do. Such an approach is favorable not only because it is more humane than the current paradigm, but because it is also more cost-effective. This is because incarceration is wildly expensive, especially in America; rehabilitation is more expensive per person, but not only do rehabilitated individuals have more opportunity to labor and contribute to the economy in the long run than do prisoners, but a post-abolition world would also have less people to rehabilitate, meaning that abolition may actually be profitable in the long term. Furthermore, incarceration has been shown to have a weak and possibly positive correlation with crime rates (that is, imprisoning people may actually decrease public safety), so a post-abolition world would also be safer. TLDR: abolition is more humane, more cost-effective, and safer than incarceration.
